Canadian arthouse landmark director Denis Villeneuve decided to finally breakthrough into U.S. market with is mainstream debut "Prisoners". In spite of the big names on the cast, Villeneuve maintains all the aspects that conform the integrity of his directing. Shots that show the tension of the situation, and clear details that impact you immediately. 

The story is slowly paced, and has many twists along side it, some working better than others, but what really prevents the running time from being a bothering aspect, is the greatly constructed characters and the respecting solid acting's from the cast. Jackman's troubled and agressive father demands your attention, but it's Gyllenhaal's meditative cop who really stands out for me. 

The grimy and bleak tone of the story is portrayed with expertise by the masterful hand of cinematographer Roger Deakins, and this really adds to the constant atmosphere of suspense. For this reason, and Villeneuve's style of direction, one might draw comparations with David Fincher's style, something that isn't actually bad per se.

The main problem with the film is its heavy-handed religious symbolism, which never really adds anything to the actual story line, and is deeply under-used. Aside from that, there are some points in the story that seem somewhat out of place, but still, these don't really ruin the viewing experience.

Overall, Prisoners is a greatly crafted Thriller, with outstanding acting's, award-worthy photography and an interesting story that keeps you hooked for its somewhat overlong running time.
Great thriller with heart
An astounding deconstruction of the father-knows-best style of action thrillers, this film presents an incredible turn for its lead, Hugh Jackman.
Excellent movie.  Really suspenseful and a twist I didn't see coming.  Huge Jackman was fantastic.

A flawlessly thematic film that enthralls the viewer while tying them into the poignant amount of ominous substance. The performances are top notch, and the writing is so gripping that you'll find yourself unbelievably excited and interested in the next on screen exchange. Prisoners can be analyzed as a symbolic, metaphorical film, as well as ringing as a horror movie for anyone close to their family. Prisoners is riveting, bold, and Denis Villeneuve's best work so far.

Perfectly balanced and absorbing.  The subject matter is disturbing but well handled, the mystery part ties everything together, and the acting is great.  One of the best thrillers I've seen in a long time.

I expected this to be a poorly written movie, relying on the cast and a kidnapping drama to draw an audience. Instead, there is no wasted dialogue or elements in the movie. It is filled with a number of motifs, symbols, and themes that leave the viewer thinking about the movie after leaving the theater. The title accurately captures the hopelessness of an inescapable fate and the haunting effect it has on families.

I'm having a lot of trouble thinking of a better film to come out in 2013. 'Prisoners' has almost everything going for it: an A list cast and director, a great story, top notch script and boat loads of tension. It fits together as intricately as the maze in its logo, and keeps the viewer on the edge of their seat until the last frame.

This film is successful for all the reasons listed above, but the story itself is the major strength. It is a slow burn style thriller that ramps up the tension in an incredibly palpable way. Starting out as a fairly straightforward abduction story, it quickly escalates into a full fledged frenzy. Twist after turn keeps the audience genuinely unsure of what is going to happen next and where it is heading. This is the ultimate job of a thriller, and this one stays one step ahead at all times. Despite this escalation, it never looses sight of what it wants to accomplish, keeping its focus on its characters and their inner struggles in a very intimate way. The ending is just right, leaving you exactly when it is supposed to.

Its characters are brought to life by some really good performances up and down the cast. Both Jackman and Gyllenhaal turn in performances worthy of being called their career bests. Gyllenhaal in particular throws himself into a very different role than he has played before, and his method acting and body language really sell it. I would cite Jackman for overacting in a few scenes, but he is very good as the father who comes to the uneasy but unapologetic realization that he will do unthinkable things to save his family. It is a very interesting dichotomy to watch someone pushed to that limit, and it leaves you with no real judgment on the morality of his character. The rest of the cast is rounded out by some great supporting performances from solid vets like Leo, Dano, Bello and Howard.

The direction is another extremely strong suit here. If you told me this was directed by David Fincher, I just might believe you. Aside from a very Fincheresque story, the direction is very much his style. Striking high contrast and lack of color saturation almost mimicking black and white photography combine with a masterful use of shot composition and symmetry that really echos Finchers directorial eye. Villeneuve is a director to watch. He's been around awhile, and while isn't particularly prolific I will be keeping an eye out for his future projects. 

There are a few minor issues I had with the film. First and foremost is its length. I'm all for a director using as much time as necessary to tell their story exactly the way they want, but I ended up feeling 153 minutes was a little much. I feel a good 15 minutes could have seen the cutting room floor without sacrificing much if anything. Another qualm I had is that after all the pain the villain ends up inflicting, I wanted to see them suffer a bit rather than the quick, arbitrary ending they are given. Is that wrong? Maybe, but I can't say I have any shame in wanting to see such a detestable character get exactly what's coming to them. A few minor issues with pacing slow things down a bit in the middle act as well. These negatives said, they are all very minor complaints that really don't do much to detract from such a great final product.

Considering the overall artistic vision, depth and effectiveness of this film on all fronts, I have to say I am fairly shocked of its lack of critical recognition and fanfare. In my opinion, this was surely deserving of several Oscar nominations and probably wins. Yet, it remains unheralded and relatively unknown to the general public for some reason. But don't let the lack of popular praise fool you: this is a grade A thriller from top to bottom, and I'd place it right at the top of best pictures of the year.

"Prisoners" brings us some relatively new faces on the creative Hollywood scene and what they bring us is completely promising if not great. Veteran Coen Brothers cinematographer Roger Deakins lends his expertise to newcomer writer Aaron Guzikowski and Director Denis Villeneuve. You can certainly see the influence of Deakins throughout the film and his beautiful take on reality in a chaotic situation.

This is one of those films that you don't want to know a thing about before you go. You don't even want to hear people brushstroke over it because even that is something you don't want to hear. For that matter, I won't even go close to going there. I will give you a brief introduction to what you should expect. Keller Dover (Hugh Jackman) and his wife Grace (Maria Bello), walk down the street to their neighbors, Franklin Birch (Terrence Howard) and Nancy (Viola Davis). They each have a daughter and along the course of the evening, those two daughters disappear without a trace.

"Prisoners" is a gut-wrenching and fast running two and a-half hour movie. It is filmed in such a way that the events that unfold could involve you, your neighbor, somebody across town and on your local news. Along with the way the movie is filmed and told, it is gifted with phenomenal actors that bring the reality of the situation to the surface.

It is an exhausting an emotionally filled movie from top to bottom and its subject matter will have your stomach in knots until the credits roll. This, quite simply, is what movies are all about. Too often these days, movies make you feel nothing. Too many directors and writers are concerned with what you see and forget that first and foremost, what makes great cinema and long lasting cinema, is the feeling it leaves in your stomach and soul. At one point, Keller Dover's sadness effected me so much that I felt as if I was actually him or in the least, one of his family members or a great friend.

"Prisoners" is the kind of movie we should be flocking to the theaters to see until Hollywood gets the message that we want to feel something. Sure, dazzle us with visuals, but until you relay empathy in your audience members, you have wasted millions of dollars and time. "Prisoners" is tremendous filmmaking. It is one of the best and most complete films of the year and will almost certainly be a member of the Oscar night nominees.

Prisoners: The Dark Side of Tragedy - 
 There is probably no greater pain then a child being taken from a parent and the fear and doubt of never knowing if you'll see that child again. Knowing that every day, every hour, every second your child could be alone, frightened, and worst of all dead. That is the dreaded crux of the core to this film. Keller (Hugh Jackman) is a rustic strong family man, raising a beautiful family. During a holiday dinner with family friends Franklin (Terrence Howard) and Nancy (Violla Davis), both of their younger daughters decide to go play outside in which they never return. The only suspect, the owner of an RV that was suspiciously parked out in the neighborhood. In comes Detective Loki (Jake Gyllenhaal) heading up the investigation of the missing children. 

 The investigation follows a strange path of multiple suspects, neither of which are connected, and the prime suspect, the first suspect, is released from holding after having absolutely no evidence to having kidnapped the children. The prime suspect, Alex (Paul Dano), is an infantile man who knows more than he is letting on. Keller having no faith in Loki's ability to find his daughter, takes matters into his own hands, kidnapping Alex himself and keeping him "prisoner", torturing and abusing him trying to get the truth from him. While Loki follows multiple leads of suspicious people, clues that don't match, incidences that turn into dead ends, Keller struggles with maintaining the guise of a father searching for his lost daughter while actually spending his time punishing Alex through violence.

 As the tale unfolds and tragedy besets both families worrisome clues start to connect and the tenuous relationship between Keller and Loki threatens the entire investigation. Loki is plagued with the desire to save the girls. As is Keller. But their methods take them to the edge of justice careening close to the depths of vengeance.

 While the entire film is tense and driven by a very powerful emotion it is not the most memorable thriller that is out there. This is based solely on the story itself. The crime and solving it is not why you watch this film. You watch this film for one of the most brilliant ensemble performances from a cast of super heavy weights, all of which give fantastic gut wrenching tear jerking performances about the pain, fear, and anger of losing a child. I think it is less about it being "memorable" in the way Se7en or Gone Baby Gone was but the performances and the wonderful cinematography by the one and only Roger Deakins makes it a strong watch. Definitely worth a view.

Prisoners is a dark and gritty movie filled with suspense and drama. This is definitely Hugh Jackman's greatest performance yet and Jake Gyllenhaal's performance  is by far the best  in the movie. This is a very solid movie all-around: good performances, good script, good direction, and great cinematography by Roger Deakins, everyone's favorite cinematographer (his other works have included most of the Coen brothers' movies, Skyfall, and The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford). It perhaps isn't quite as important or Oscar-worthy as it seems to think it is, but it's a really compelling film nevertheless.
Hugh Jackman stars as a blue-collar guy whose 6-year-old daughter is kidnapped. Jake Gyllenhaal plays the detective investigating the case, in a surprisingly interesting performance. When Jackman's character quickly grows frustrated with the police's lack of progress, he decides to do some investigating himself, kidnapping a potential suspect (Paul Dano, typecast yet again as a creepy weirdo) and torturing him for information.

The movie's plot, as it moves along, can seem fairly standard, though there are definitely some late-game twists I didn't see coming. What's more remarkable about the film is its constant sense of gray, rainy misery, which is really bolstered by Roger Deakins's work. The movie doesn't have as many pointedly stylish shots as, say, Skyfall, but it does a great job with shadows and darkness. It's arguably a good example of a color film noir, at least in the visual style of certain scenes. To be honest, at its core, this could have been an average movie, but the talent of everyone involved raised it considerably. It's a good example, not of style over substance, but of style aiding substance.

Denis Villeneuve's Prisoners is a fantastic movie that made me took notice of the director. I know that the film's plot has been done before in other films or TV shows, but it's the execution that makes it stand out which is very effectively done. Hugh Jackman gives a powerhouse performance and gives it his all that I find him very convincing, and I was surprised that he didn't get nominated for an Academy Award in this. Jake Gyllenhaal is fantastic in this and Maria Bello gives an emotional performance that you can see how broken her character was after her child had been kidnapped. Paul Dano, Melissa Leo, Viola Davis, and Terrence Howard are really good that there is no actor that wasn't bad in this. The script by Aaron Guzikowski is very well-written that it really made the film more complex than to get the audience invested, but not too complex to lose the viewers and get very confused. The characters are simple, but memorable enough that you really want the main characters to find their daughters, even when they take Paul Dano's character hostage. It really gets tense at times, and the reveal is really good. Prisoners is a very smart film that got me riveted from beginning to end.

Inside the frame of a very simple kidnapping story is a thickly layered and fascinatingly ambiguous exploration of faith, luck, coincidence, and justice. There's something fundamentally human about the story, but Denis Villeneuve also weaves in an ominous sense of cultural desperation that seems to originate from 9/11.

Hugh Jackman is, as always, excellent as the father whose rationality becomes increasingly clouded by rage. The movie really belongs to Jake Gyllenhaal though, as the investigating officer who is equally frustrated by the constraints of the legal system and also a slave to its proven methods.
"Pray for the best, but prepare for the worst."

I usually hear people say they dislike this movie because it was "not enjoyable" or "too dark."  I was disappointed to see it overlooked for acting Academy nods, but in a year full of Oscar bait, I shouldn't have been surprised.  Well, I for one am not afraid of a little darkness - or even a lot, as in this case.

The performances here are sublime.  Hugh Jackman is a force of nature as a father channeling the fear for his daughter into brutal action.  Jake Gyllenhaal is the detached, perceptive detective with little tolerance for human interaction.  But the real treat is Paul Dano, who manages to be menacing, meek, and empathetic without saying very much at all. 

Combine all this with immersive cinematography and a gripping plot, and you've got yourself a gaze into the abyss of what humans are willing to do to find answers.

On the surface, Prisoners is a child abduction movie with all the usual elements: distraught parents looking mourning their lost children, police detectives searching for answers as the clock ticks, and a creepy antagonist with an immoral purpose for kidnapping children. Digging deeper, the film is about morality and the loss of morality when tragedy strikes. The mystery keeps you guessing until the end the reveal is far less shocking as the transformation each character undergoes. The film is disturbing, but not so disturbing that it's inaccessible. Instead, the film digs under your skin and tries to include you in the suffering the parents are going through. You want answers not because you're curious about the outcome, but because you genuinely want to see the conflict resolved. Everyone is excellent in term of performance and the film is well written. There are a few scenes I thought could have been executed better, but for the most part the film is exceptional. I would recommend watching it, but I'll only sit through it once.

While this was a very good, emotionally wrenching film, it was just not as good as it could have been. Jake Gyllenhaal delivers one of his best performances in a long time (I'm tempted to say since Brokeback Mountain, seriously), as his Detective Loki was the right amount of measured intensity and anguish. Conversely, Hugh Jackman's performance, while good, is just a little over the top. An emotionally powerful performance doesn't always involve screaming at the top of your lungs in every scene and unfortunately that's the lasting impression I had from him here. 

I also found the story suffered from a few too many plot holes in my opinion. Having said that, the Denis Villeneuve did a fantastic job of creating a dark, cold, dreadful atmosphere that permeated the film and really created a sense of despair. I enjoyed this much more than I did his most recent film (Enemy). Overall, I would say this is worth seeing, especially for Gyllenhaal's underrated performance alone.

The best film of 2013. This movie made you scared, tense, and sad, all indications that a crime thriller has done its job. Hugh Jackman should have won an Academy award, playing as a dad who will do anything to find his kidnapped daughter and hia friend's daughter, even if that means they must break the law. As for the cop from Zodiac, he deserved to be nominated for an Oscar as well, as we see the change from a calm, helping cop to a mess at the end. Prisoners has a very strong draw. The story pulls you in almost immediately and does a great job of not letting go. The immediate premise alone is horrific to extreme levels and its possibility is so real that it can put its viewers in a very vulnerable emotional place. There are particular aspects that place viewers in this state but not in an overtly obvious way. The structure takes its time to draw us in while feeding us tiny moments of youthful innocence that serves to trigger a sentimentality that quite literally sneaks up on us. All the while at the same time we are faced with feeling of complete dread as the story unfolds.  You may begin to feel as helpless as some of the characters facing this nightmare. 
    
       The imagery in this film is scattered but grotesquely beautiful. We have the whistle, which is always red, the images of the mazes, the Cross, snakes, and the manikins; none of which have too much purpose save for making the situation more bizarre and disturbing. The storyline all-together is intriguing enough though without all that extra imagery. Where the story truly pulls you in is in the behavior of Keller (Hugh Jackman) to the situation. I've read some believe he "over acts" but I don't agree with that at all given the circumstances. Keller's intensity is completely believable though his actions are extreme. Detective Loki (Gyllenhaal) is only slightly developed beyond his involvement of the case but we are given subtle glimpses at who he might be which suggests he is actually the perfect man for the case. He ought to be since his office seems to be fairly incompetent and leaves him without a partner on this investigation.

   I felt the cinematography was sufficient but not something to lose yourself in. The editing is very good as it allows you time to soak in the moments that are the most critical. Too often do films rush us through a roller coaster while we miss all emotion stimulation. The music is dreary with its use of violins and synthesizers and does a good job working with the footage. 

  Prisoners is a good film for those who enjoy thrillers. I recommend giving it a watch.

Glylenhaal's Detective Loki's cool and professional attitude to crime solving contrasts starkly with Hugh Jackman's Keller Dover, a man distraught by  and driven to find his missing daughter. In this dark and moody scenario, Director Denis Villeneuve explores the question of what actions parents will take trying to save their children, and what rationale they will use to justify those actions. Prisoners is a very complexly crafted thriller that gets under your skin on many emotional levels, Richly Acted, Beautifully Filmed, Disturbingly Twisted, solidly writed and throughoutly suspenseful that holds tight the viewer, without a doubt worth watching.

Prisoners effortlessly stages its dark, foreboding tone from the outset. Of course the audience knows that all is not well in this suburban-Pennsylvania town; we've seen the previews, we know the story. Keller Dover (Hugh Jackman) knows what can go wrong as well. An out-of-work carpenter, Jackman phenomenally brings to life the survivalist mentality which has dictated and guided his life up to the beginning of the film: the day that his daughter is stolen from him. 

This film is brooding,accentuated by a palate of grays and blacks, but fully brought to life by complex performances by Jake Gyllenhaal as the detective charged with returning the girls to safety, as well as Melissa Leo, who adds another polished role to her resume on par with her portrayal of Alice Ward in The Fighter. Detective Loki (Gyllenhaal) plays a foil of sorts to Dover, and he always inexplicably knows where to find the dead body (he's never failed to close a case). Screenwriter Aaron Guzikowski doesn't go so far as to make us doubt Loki's motives, only to question his background and breadth of knowledge about such a dark world. We're never privy to many of these answers.

If Prisoners misses the mark anywhere, it is in length. This weighty slog thrills and holds our pulses high, but at two hours and thirty-three minutes, we're completely devoid of the ability to take any more. I liken Prisoners to getting smacked across the face, but the reward for your endurance is an extraordinary film, reaching the upper echelon of the genre. You'll be ready for a walk after the lights go up,yet the plot never drags. Like any crime thriller, certain tangents and red herrings are followed to a fault. However, these ploys successfully disguise other critical elements of the trail, enabling them to go unnoticed until their importance needs to be revisited. Loki misses these details simply because of the mass of evidence he has to investigate; Dover misses them because he is otherwise distracted in a gritty battle that is sure to test your stomach. 

This film succeeds because it keeps its foot on the accelerator. A story like Prisoners has a tendency to either slow to a halt about twenty minutes before the climax, or rely on a character to break the tension from time to time.Director Denis Villeneuve decided to rise above that. Rather than cheapen a well-written script with a sideshow or a plot intermission, he keeps the tension high thanks to a deathly quiet soundtrack, a multitude of parallel stories, and depth to characters fully brought out by this incredible cast. 

Prisoners is taxing and cumbersome. The darkness of the subject entraps you and will force you to consider what you just saw. But isn't that what movies are supposed to do?

For a 'catch the bad guy' film, this one is particularly divisive due to its unnerving brutality. As the film nears its end whilst only managing to become darker and more unpleasant, it's clear that the viewer is either going to be trapped in the clutches of its horrid atmosphere or they're going to have drawn the line and wished they'd never started watching to begin with. Either way, the film's commitment to its pitch-black atmosphere makes it something relatively unique for the genre.

You'll certainly feel queasy after this one and its cruelty that verges on sadism will be enough to put many off. If, like myself, you decide not to draw the line and let that go as it were then you may still feel that this film was a missed opportunity through its emphasis on being a crime thriller rather than the human drama that turns out only being a sliver of the overall work. Still, if you want a crime thriller that'll keep you engaged whilst being memorable and feeling somewhat distinct from the genre as a whole, then this is for you.

The plot just manages to tow the line between being interesting and simply becoming overly-ridiculous. It's certainly convoluted and not as smart as it wants to be (you could figure most of it out pretty early on if you tried) but it does a good job in creating convincing mystery and uncertainty within its characters as the story develops. Even if the viewer does say enough is enough as the plot twists and turns, they'll still be tied to how the characters react to these developments. It's still a little ridiculous though if I'm honest!

The cast fit well and never seem out of place. Jackman, who I'm honestly not particularly fond of, fits this role like a glove and felt like smart casting for a character that seems to be driven more by revenge than by sorrow. Gyllenhaal overdid it a little for me at times- trying a little too hard to be the damaged cop however he doesn't become a caricature and he doesn't bring the film down at all. 

Dano ultimately doesn't get to do much which is disappointing but he plays his part well- the same could be said of Howard, Bello, and Davis, whose characters all may as well have been named 'distraught person crying' as none of them ever really step into the story in their own way. Due to its focus on atmosphere and its trying-too-hard plot, this film could easily have fallen apart with a lesser cast so its good to see them meeting expectations here.

The film has a very interesting premise as the response of Jackman's character to the abduction of his daughter serves as half of  the film's main focus, with the search for the criminal serving as the other half. This makes it stand out a little but in the end it's rather disappointing as the story veers more and more towards your typical crime thriller until Jackman's character just serves as an extension of that. The opportunities to discuss the moral and ethical implications of Davis' actions end up completely lost to the more formulaic aspects of the crime thriller parts of the story. As a result, the film slowly becomes less-interesting, despite the plot continuing to move at a decent pace.

This is my main issue with the film and there's really no excuse for it. It has a fairly significant runtime and yet it's paced well enough to avoid feeling painfully long and dragged on. Why some of this time wasn't used to focus on the moral struggle surrounding the events in the film is a question worth asking as it certainly would have enhanced the impact of the movie. It's certainly haunting when all is said and done but it's a particularly queasy feeling as opposed to an emotional one that the viewer is left with. It's an all-visceral response that this film brings out and I'd have preferred something more emotional and introspective in the end which this film didn't seem particularly interested in.

Overall, if you can accept its overbearingly depressing nature, then you've got something here that stands out from your average crime thriller, even if it does seem to have let itself down a little.

"a gritty, incredibly well-acted, suspenseful, thought-provoking crime drama thriller" 
Wow, what an intensely suspenseful film Prisoners was. The film commences with a naturalistic and peaceful look of a suburban neighborhood, leafless trees calmly swaying along with the cool air that encompass them. All is fine, and a perfectly normal family visits their friends/neighbors for a delightful dinner and some music. Everything is fine and dandy until both family's two kids run off to retrieve a toy they left outside. After pleasant conversation, the two families begin to realize that their kids haven't gotten back yet. The noiseless environment around them feels incredibly unusual, and once they realize that their kids have officially gone missing, chaos breaks loose. We are suddenly presented with a ruthless father (played by Hugh Jackman) who loves his daughter so much that he's willing to transcend any morally difficult obstacles to hopefully locate her. 

A spectacular cast, ranging from the likes of Hugh Jackman to Jake Gyllenhaal to Viola Davis and Terrence Howard, create such a chilling atmosphere that everyone in the audience immediately notices the discomforting subject matter as they prepare for a disturbing viewing. One should know prior to visiting the movie theater that this film doesn't feature morally perfect individuals. They are all human beings cast into an unbelievably frightening situation, and this is where larges amounts of debate will stir. There's one side of the audience that will persistently detest the characters' actions and the characters themselves, and there's the other side (which I am proudly a part of) that will essentially understand that people can't possibly (always) be the "goody-two-shoes" heroes, perceived in Hollywood blockbusters, in reality- that, by god, I will partake morally and ethically questionable activities to save a precious, loved one, absolutely! Such conversation/argument is healthy for it proves the memorability factor of the film itself. After you witness the terrifically-crafted picture, you will find enjoyment in discussing the movie's events with friends and family with- eventually- two sides forming over the talk. 

And holy crap is Hugh Jackman entirely convincing in his performance. You can see the longing to find his sweet, innocent daughter through his miserable eyes, filled with redness, desperation, and anger. Then, there's Jake Gyllenhaal as the second lead, playing an ambitious cop who holds a very impressive resume: no unsolved cases left under his plate. Can that mean his skill will greatly help in this predicament? On a similar note, Paul Dano takes the prize after Hugh Jackman for another wonderful performance. No offense or anything, but he completely fits into these immensely creepy and eerie roles. 

Speaking of, the soundtrack will definitely remain in that shocked mind of yours long after you've left the theater because it fills us with a sense of hopelessness and discomfort. At times, it sounds exceptionally ominous with the disconcerting sound of those violins in play. At others, it sounds like the music weeps for all those involved. The pace never seems to drag even though it clocks in at around 150 minutes as you remain at the edge of seat the entire time, utterly perplexed by everything that's transpiring and wholly befuddled by the choices that these people are making. The film will make you cringe and question the humanity of the participants or the competence of our law (that word could mean two things). Although I was slightly disappointed with the end result, the majority of the film strongly intrigued me. And, oh, how could I forget, the cinematography is simply amazing. Roger Deakins, the brilliant cinematographer behind last year's Skyfall, manages the camera-work of this film as well. As one wise critic said, a drive in the rain never felt so disquieting- a moment of foreboding. 

Furthermore, I would not recommend skipping out on Prisoners unless you're of the type that prefers more lighthearted and fun movies like The Avengers. If you love films that explore more than just entertainment and "fun," such as important themes and moral ambiguity as a whole, you cannot go wrong with Prisoners. With a mix of top-notch cinematography, remarkably unsettling music, superb performances, and a thrilling/powerful story, Prisoners will definitely be one of this year's features that I'll surely be remembering. The true cinema season has started; now, let's hope every film from here on out delivers like this one did.

After a man's daughter is kidnapped, he resort to torturing the police's prime suspect in order to discover her whereabouts.
As a thriller, this film follows the basic genre conventions.  It's tense, mysterious, and occasionally compelling.  However, it seems the film's ambitions are beyond a basic genre film.  A lot of the film's exposition establishes Keller Dover (Hugh Jackman) as a survivalist -- a right-wing, anti-establishmentarian -- in order to explain his extreme behavior later.  But this theme remains undeveloped.  I can imagine a good film that questions whether a man's personal moral compass should override the moral compass that most reasonable people agree to, but by the second act, the film devolves into torture porn and the generic dramatic questions overtake the film's philosophical musings.
Jackman has never been an impressive actor, and what depth we see in Keller comes from the script, not his performance.  The same can be said of Jake Gyllenhaal, and unfortunately the plot renders Maria Bello catatonic halfway through the film.  The best performance is by Paul Dano, who never fails to impress.
Overall, as a thriller, Prisoners fits the genre, but as anything more, it's close but not quite.

An extremely well-crafted and almost criminally underrated movie that is one of my all-time favorites. Prisoners does absolutely everything I want in a psychological mystery thriller drama and more with its incredible acting, fantastic directing, and very smart script that make for a psychologically disturbing, atmospherically dreadful and intense, and always involving watch despite a 153-minute runtime. I also consider this one of the biggest Oscar snubs of all-time with Hugh Jackman not getting nominated for one of my favorite performances of all-time, as well as other snubs with Jake Gyllenhaal, Paul Dano, Melissa Leo, Denis Villeneuve for Best Directing, Aaron Guzikowski for Best Original Screenplay, and obviously Best Picture. I strongly recommend it if you've never seen it.

First off Paul Dano is amazing in this movie, Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal were solid as well. The film had me and the wife right from the start, and at no point were we bored. Towards the end we were shocked by the twist in the film. I can't recommend this film enough. If you like gripping suspense dramas than this is the film for you.
Great movie! Would have liked a little more closure at the ending.

PRISONERS is compelling, beautifully shot and brilliantly directed- from a technical standpoint. There are some truly brilliant things about this movie- and there are some rather bad things about it. I mentioned some ofthe brilliant things in this movie. 

Now let me explain some of the bad things: Hugh Jackman's overacted performance (his facial expressions look about as real as SOUTH PARK's visuals), some poor story construction, many unnecessary scenes, the film is overlong, Melissa Leo's overwritten character, some aspects of Terrence Howard's performance, and a few relatively unimportant things. Jake Gyllenhaal and Paul Dano, however, are both great all the way through; and the way director Denis Villeneuve retains the sense of dread throughout is almost masterful. 

What's really scary is that Jackman's character is actually capable of going so far mentally outside his comfort zone to get his daughter back. Now over the past few years I personally have learned a lot (and am still learning) about self-control; but his character is scary; unfortunately Jackman's over-acting really does not help this character's credibility- in fact, I had a hard time believing him. He achieved the basics of the performance- character establishment- but none of the more complex parts of the performance, unfortunately. 

Overall, it's a very good movie- difficult to watch, but I will say it's worth it.
This film has Hugh Jackman at his best once again!!! How far would you go to get back the ones you love?

The movie in which Terrance Howard cries a lot, Viola Davis stares blankly and stutters, and Maria Bello sleeps.  Hugh Jackman tries hard to show 'man possessed' rage, but shares too much screen time with Gyllenhall's fast blinking detective.  Once the 2.5 hours draws to its obvious conclusion - it's hard to remember what you liked about the film.

Right out of the gate this film will grab hold on you and not let go until the end credits roll.  Hugh Jackman steals the show with his performance of a father who will go to any extreme to find his daughter.  The complexities of this film leave the viewer to ask themselves "is that going too far?" What is right and what is wrong? How far are you willing to go to protect your children?

To echo other reviewers, "just how far would you go?" is a very real question indeed. This movie is a slow burn for sure but also very worth it! Hackman and Gyllenhaal are excellent as are the rest of the cast!

A rare breed of flick that does everything it sets out to do. Brutal (a bit) but it's genuine, powerful and even inspiring. I'm sure that every parent who's experienced a moment of terror wondering where their child is- will whole heartedly share empathy and perhaps even cheer for the films characters.

Loved it! Felt very real...and things that Hugh Jackman does are things I would do or expect my husband to do, in this situation. Jake Gyllenhaal was intense and very believable. Hard to believe this movie was overlooked!
Thanks for the recommendation, Tarin! Great film!
One of the Best movies I have seen in the last few years! Intense and superb performances by Hugh Jackman  Jake Gylenhaal and Maria Bello ! This movie should have gotten an Oscar nod!!!

God damn is Hugh Jackman one scary son of a bitch! For almost a year now friends have been telling me that I needed to see this and it is very realistic and all that other stuff. So I decided one weekend, "What the hell" and rent the movie only to finish it off and say to myself "WHAT THE HELL?" From I hear this is something that people say that it is one of the best movies of 2013. It's one of those movies that did really well at the Toronto International Film Festival so I can say that there are some I get what they're talking about and some things that I can't. This is a pretty dark film and a really cool mystery, so let me dive right on in this movie.

The movie brings a lot of things to the table with one of which being is this right or wrong when you do what you have to do in order to find your children? Like the degree to which they lose all sense of their sensibility to become this crazy person who morality becomes neither here nor there and the only thing that matters is them and their own shit. Hugh Jackman gives, without a doubt, one of the best performances that I have ever seen in his entire career. He delivers a mixture of seriousness and animosity that makes you believe that there are people like this that do exist out there in the real world. I mean if you put his character in a room with the Hugh Jackman version of Wolverine, there's no doubt that he'll beat the ever loving shit out of the mutant. I'm going to tell you something else, if you want someone to play nervous in your movies then get Terrance Howard. This guy plays nervous like nobody else. I loved Jake Gyllenhaal in here as well as plays this stressed out detective who is constantly frustrated whenever he can't solve a clue or when the parents are his back about the case. Everyone else in here from Paul Dano to Maria Bello, and even Melissa Leo were spectacular in this movie and not a single role felt like it was wasted. One complaint I had with this is that this movie is two and a half hours and there are scenes in here that just drags on for so long that they could've easily taken it out. The whole middle act has this whole morality play that is not really going anywhere about Hugh Jackman having this guy tied up certain that he is the one who did it and you're like "Okay maybe we should have something else happening in the plot that moves the story along. It could lose some people when they watch this, but it didn't lose me. Overall I enjoyed the hell out of this movie and if you have a lot of time to kill then I recommend this. This is, without a doubt, a solid four stars all the way.
Despite some flaws it's definitely worth watching.

I did feel like it left a few questions unanswered such as in relation to the culprit's motives but I'm not sure whether that is due to the film's failure to clarify a few details or a lack of concentration on my part. Prepare for a long, slow-boiling suspense / thriller, but in the end it's a great mind-bending exercise that will keep you thinking. Dark and foreboding, this movie is at times hauntingly authentic in its portrayal of the desperation and determination of a loving and distraught father. It shows how one heinous act creates not only more victims, but more monsters. Worth a viewing if you're in to crime dramas. Rating: 7/10

I understood exactly what Prisoners was. The characters, timeline, motivations. No question was left unexplained, no element left unexplored. I finished watching the movie with no doubt that I didn't miss anything. Yet for several days, it hasn't left my mind. It's an uncanny accomplishment to make a film that is truly more than the sum of its parts, which is exactly what Prisoners is.

I'll begin with the cast, because the acting on display here is both vitally important to the film, and excellent. Hugh Jackman plays Keller Dover, a God fearing survivalist who is disempowered from his state of readiness when his daughter is kidnapped alongside one of his neighbours. He plays the character in an extremely raw and emotionally driven way, which acts to counterbalance the cooler, collected Detective Loki played by Jake Gyllenhaal. He too is at the top of his game, alongside a formidable supporting cast including Terrence Howard and Viola Davis.

The exceptional cast is helped by a screenplay which never stops putting the audience through their paces...

Wow.  This might be the best replicant of a Christopher Nolan or early M Night Shyamalan film (more so the religious aspects) in the decade so far (sorry Wally Pfister).  Coming to mind, the film is heavily similar to Insomnia, probably one of Nolan's more conventional films, but the ideas and cinematic flair are still present here.  Again, the twist isn't too shocking (especially again if you know the pedigree of the casting....) but it's still one that keeps you guessing throughout the entire film.  Jackman and Gyllenhaal really carry the movie with decent performances from the supporting.  It's sadly way too long.  If the movie focused more on Loki vs Jackman's torturing, I think it could had had a slicker feel to it.  Instead, you just keep wishing it go back to the story instead of the meaningless red herrings.  Overall, it's a strong movie and a recommendation (which I don't say often), but it's more a "one and done" great story like Insomnia was, versus one that needs to be returned to to find everything it offers.  There is complexity in their natures, but it overall doesn't fully reach its needed potential.

Directed by French-Canadian filmmaker Denis Villeneuve, (Maelström (2000), Incendies (2011) and Enemy (2013)) and written by Aaron Guzikowski (Contraband (2012)), this dark and brooding crime thriller is one which will require your patience but it is well worth it. The success of the film is down to a really intricate plot and a terrific cast, all putting some magnificent and electrifying performances. Carpenter Keller Dover (Hugh Jackman) is a very devout Catholic whose family goes for Thanksgiving dinner with their neighbours, Franklyn and Nancy Birch (Terrence Howard and Viola Davis). After dinner, the families girls Anna Dover (Erin Gerasimovich) and Joy Birch (Kyla Drew Simmons) go missing, prompting a search led by Detective Loki (Jake Gyllenhaal). The main suspect is Alex Jones (Paul Dano), who had an RV parked nearby, but Jones has the mental age of a little boy, and they can't prove he did it. Dover believes Jones did it, so he takes the law into his own hands, but Loki discovers some dark secrets about this particular case. It's a film you will need to watch again, as all the clues are spread throughout the film, but they're not very clear, and you will need to pay attention to. However, it all makes sense in the end, and nothing in this mystery is what it seems, and everyone, even the innocent parties, all have skeletons in the closet.

The psychological thriller Prisoners is a daring and edgy film that tackles some challenging issues.  When the police fail to build a case against a suspected child abductor, Keller Dover takes matters into his own hands and attempts to torture a confession out of the suspect in order get his daughter back.  Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal lead the cast and give outstanding performances.  And, the film does a good job at making the audience feel the intensity, suspense, and exhaustion involved in the search for the abducted child.  However, there are some pacing issues, as the plot seems to drag and meander at points.  Yet even with rough edges, Prisoners is a provocative and compelling film.

Thanksgiving is a time of love and gratitude, cherishing jubilant moments over a warm, oven-roasted turkey around a table with family and friends. This is precisely what the Birch and Dover families, whom are neighbors and close friends, are expecting when attending a Thanksgiving dinner at the Birch residence. There is a deep sense of comfort and connectedness between the two families as they prepare for their quiet, pleasant evening. With a title like Prisoners, it comes as no surprise that the events in this film do not unfold peacefully for these charming families.

The grizzly events of Prisoners begin when Anna Dover and Joy Birch, the two six-years-olds from each respective family, decide to play outdoors. They are accompanied by their older siblings and soon come across what appears to be an abandoned RV, which the two young girls begin to climb before their older siblings force them off as they return for dinner. It is only shortly before dinner that both families realize their two six-year-old daughters are nowhere to be found, and upon searching their homes and the surrounding area, panic begins to set in. 

The authorities are contacted immediately, and Detective Loki, played by Jake Gyllenhaal, leads the case. He takes a detailed account of the events that took place before the girls went missing, and shortly thereafter, he finds the RV by which the girls had played. A young man residing inside the RV is then arrested for the accused kidnapping, but further investigation proves it is highly improbable for this man to be the skilled kidnapper-he has the IQ of an average 10-year-old and is awkwardly simple-minded. The plot thickens as Keller Dover, played by Hugh Jackman, decides to take matters into his own hands and find the two missing girls himself, using unskillful detective-work and sadistically violent measures as he sees fit. Keller and Detective Loki progressively discover that there are a multitude of complex clues they must piece together in this intense enigma if they hope to find the two young girls alive.

While slow-paced at times, Prisoners never fails to keep you gripped, scanning every shot for clues and questioning the trustworthiness of each character. Like the title of the film, we too become prisoners of the crime and the agitation the young girls and their distraught families are experiencing. Prisoners is by no means a blissful or straightforward film. However, it reaches deeply into the heart of humanity and the darkness that we are capable of as human beings, whether for love or for malice.
On the slow side, but the story works well, the performances are great all around, and the cinematography is breathtaking.

Prisoners had a lot to live up to. Just look at that cast; Hugh Jackman, Jake Gyllenhaal, Viola Davis, Melissa Leo, etc. All actors at least nominated for Oscars, if not having actually won them. There is a lot of talent acting in the film, but any actor is only as good as the material they are handed. So what was the end result?

In short, the most gripping, edge of your seat film I have ever seen. I have never been floored by a movie, or infused with so much anxiety from a film. I was shaking, and hardly able to stand up from my seat as the credits rolled. I don't have many criticisms of this film myself, but I'd like to refute many of the criticism I've seen below.
The most common aspect of the film I've seen complained about is the length. The film is long, running at just under 2 hours and 30 minutes. It has been said that the film delves down every avenue, guiding the viewer through sequences that may not be necessary to the overall plot of the film.

I couldn't disagree more.

The film may be long, but it never felt long to me because every single scene felt completely essential to the film, even if it didn't seem so at the time, by the end, it all comes together. Sure, they could have streamlined the narrative, made it a little more linear, but the film would have suffered for it. The film is littered with characters, but that long running time gives us more than enough time to spend time with them, get to know them, and let them develop properly.

It also gives the film time to completely subvert your expectations of it multiple times. There will, undoubtedly, be several times during the film that you will think you've got it all figured out, but then something will happen that completely throws you off. But then, it will do it again. And at the end, you may end up somewhere that is somewhat predictable, but the journey of how you get there is thrilling.

Another complaint I've seen echoed from several reviewers is with the brutality of the film. But the violence of the film serves a greater purpose, conveys the social commentary on display, and isn't just violence for the sake of violence or shock value. Now, the violence is shocking, but in context, and with relation to the overall narrative, it is essential. How far would a parent go to find their children? Or, what lengths would a parent go to comfort themselves, and convince themselves their child is still alive? The film asks one of these questions, but leaves it up to you to decide which one.

I'd urge you, that if you see the film, pay attention and appreciate every detail. Even when you may think the narrative is losing its way, stay vigil, because the payoff for everything will be there in the end. The last 30 minutes of this film will surprise you and have you on edge like you may never have been before. Everything comes together in that span of time, but it does not feel like it is rushing towards a conclusion, in the traditional sense. It is more like it is rocketing towards a finale that is fast and frantic because it has to be.

I apologize if it seems I am beating around the bushes on some of these subjects, but I absolutely abhor reviews that are unable to tell you what is great about a film without telling you exactly what happens. Spoilers are a big deal to me, and many others, and I try to keep that in mind.

Although Hugh Jackman has top billing, to me Jake Gyllenhaal steals the show here. His character of Detective Loki is most of the time a very subdued character, but he always gives off the sense that something much more is boiling beneath the surface. And when that side of him comes out, Gyllenhaal is a complete and utter powerhouse. Don't get me wrong; Hugh Jackman does wonderful work here, but if you've seen Hugh Jackman before, even just as Wolverine, you'll know that he can pull off angry and ferocious. It's good work, but it's nothing quite out of his wheelhouse. Even all the supporting roles are great and well acted, because the receive the screen time they need to have a full arc as characters.

I don't think I could gush any more about Prisoners without going into specifics, but in short, I implore you to see this movie. If you're a fan of great drama, horror, or just movies in general, this will be a very enjoyable, although somewhat brutal, breath of fresh air. If it meets all the foolish Oscar qualifying guidelines, this will, without a doubt, be one to watch in the coming award season.

"Prisoners"  (2013)  
by Ricky Miller


I have a hard time watch anything involved with children. Whether it's the Oscar-winning "Sophie's Choice" wherein Meryl Streep had to decide on letting which child live or die.  Or even more recently in the overrated "Mystic River" which to me felt like a gloried made-for-TV movie of the week.  More recently "The Impossible" dealt with a separated family (Naomi Watts and Ewan McGregor) who helped each other out after a giant tsunami.
Empathy factor runs high on this compelling drama in which Jackman's 7- year-old daughter goes missing after a Thanksgiving rendezvous. I would say I really didn't enjoy this flick, but more or less respected what first time director Denis Villenueve was trying to accomplish with this pretzel twisting  mystery/thriller.  
A heavily tattooed Jake Gyllenhaal is the cop assigned to help Jackman's Keller Dover track down the logistics in figuring out the dynamics of the strange case.  
Paul Dano, so good in the little seen "The Girl Next Door" and Paul Anderson's "There Will be Blood" underplays his role as Alex Jones, a kid who has no more than an 8th grade education.  Even though one feels his pain, one can't help but to be dumbfounded by his predicament.  
Rounding out the cast in great support are Terrence Howard, Viola Davis, Maria Bello and Oscar winner Melissa Leo as Holly Jones, Alex's caregver.
A tough flick to endure, "Prisoners" at least ends with a glimmer of surprise and hope by film's end.

But I'm always ready for a creepy thriller, especially one that features Jake Gyllenhaal and this one is beautifully shot by Roger Deakins.  Hugh Jackman leaves his Wolverine Muttonchops on the makeup stand for a while to portray the proactive father of one of the missing girls and while the entire cast is spot-on, it's the twists and turns that are the heart of this movie.  In a world full of predictability, I found this to be a more interesting ride than I bargained for.  It's terrifying and dark, mostly because of its plausibility, but it feels like a hidden gem in a year that was full of some very good films, and some very over-hyped films.

Prisoners (Denis Villeneuve, 2013)

I'll be up front with you: I am writing the first sentences of this review, which I expect will be a very long one, without knowing what rating I will actually be giving Prisoners. I believe that somewhere over the course of the thousands of reviews I have written (Amazon is home to over six thousand of them as of this writing, on October 5, 2013, and I had been reviewing steadily for longer before I started posting there than I have been since I started, so you can do the math...) that has probably happened before...but I can't remember it, if it has. I have a great deal to mull over before figuring that out, I think. I liked it, overall; there is a great deal to like about it. It is surprisingly well-paced for having come out of a film culture where directors are actively encouraged to make their films about half as long as this one (this is the only film I have seen made in the last fifteen years that is this long that is not either (a) a musical, (b) a Shah Rukh Khan vehicle, or (c ) both of the above), it is unflinching in its examination of violence, its script is intelligent and multi-layered (though it does overplay its hand now and again), it is impeccably-cast, and I could keep going like this all night without really digging into the film at all. But it is not perfect, and while I admit I finished watching it less than an hour and a half before I am writing the opening words of this review, the more I think about the nagging questions I walked out of the theater with, the more they nag at me. Time will tell (and probably will, before I finish writing this review, which will probably be a few weeks from now-if I follow standard operating procedure with it, anyway) if they continue to nag, but the biggest thing that bothered me, and my first impression is that much of this comes from Jake Gyllenhaal being one of the male leads, is that I saw a lot of Zodiac in this movie. I also saw a lot of Snowtown, which is harder to explain away. That made some of what unfolded on the screen before me more predictable than, I think, it should have been; almost certainly more than screenwriter Aaron Guzikowski (Contraband) intended. But we shall see after I keep mulling it over; I'm going to go do some more of that right now.

Plot: Keller Dover (X-Men's Hugh Jackman) and Frankin Burch (Hustle and Flow's Terrence Howard) are friends in the suburbs. They get together for Thanksgiving; their daughters go out, saying they're heading over to the other house to do whatever it is that preteen girls do away form the prying eyes of their parents. They never make it. Suspicion is immediately cast on a broken-down old camper that has been seen in the area; when the police track it down in the dark corner of a convenience store parking lot, they find its driver to be young mentally-challenged Alex Jones (The Good Heart's Paul Dano). The police, in the form of one Detective Loki (The Day After Tomorrow's Jake Gyllenhaal), interrogate Jones, but do not have enough evidence to go anywhere with it; he is ultimately released, leading Dover to take matters into his own hands. Initially, Burch goes along with Dover's plan for extracting information, but the longer things go one, the more Dover pulls away not only from Burch, but from the rest of his life. Eventually, people start noticing that Alex has gone missing, and Detective Loki's focus hones in on Dover.

And now back to my initial paragraph, which I wrote five months before this one. About 80% of this movie is phenomenal, a thought-provoking journey into the motivations and actions of people who are driven to desperation. The other 20% feels as if it were tacked on for a commercial audience who would not be satisfied with that and needed some sort of conventional mystery to resolve. It's trite, relies on plot twists you've seen in half a hundred other movies of its ilk, and while it is as well-presented as the rest of the movie-these are all fine actors turning in fine performances, Villeneuve (Incendies) certainly knows his way around a camera, and  Roger Deakins was nominated for an Oscar for his chilling cinematography (he lost to, of course, Gravity)-it still feels kind of like the old Irving Pichel trick of "hey, we finished shooting a week early and have some extra stock, let's make another movie!"...except this time they stitched the two together, and the graft didn't quite take. The straight mystery at the end is watchable, but in juxtaposition to the drama/thriller/horror film that comes before it, it pales. Should you see it? Absolutely. Is it, as IMDB would have us believe as I am writing this in March 2014, one of the 250 best movies ever made (it is sitting at #249)? Not on your life. ***  1/2

"A FATHER TRYING TO FIND TWO MISSING GIRLS"  

- 'Prisoners' is a 2013 mystery thriller starring Hugh Jackman (The Prestige, X-men), Jake Gyllenhaal (Donnie Darko, Brokeback Mountain), Terrence Howard (Crash, Iron Man) and Melissa Leo (Red State, The Fighter). The story is about two girls who have disappeared and the search of their family and a policeman. This strong film lets us see how far people are willing to go to find the ones they miss. Unforgettable twists and powerful performances make this a must-see movie that will linger on for a couple of days. How far would you go? 

Keller Dover (Jackman) and his family attend a thanksgiving party at the house of their neighbors, the Birches. When the two youngest children, Anna Dover and Joy Birch, go missing, Keller and Franklin Birch (Howard) search the whole neighborhood. Keller's son Ralph tells them he noticed a strange RV down the street when he went for a walk with the girls. Detective David Loki (Gyllenhaal) is assigned to the case of the missing girls and it doesn't take him long to find the RV and its driver; Alex Jones.

Alex is taken to the police station to be questioned. But the man is disabled and has the IQ of a child. As the investigators retrieve no information, Alex is released. His aunt Holly (Leo) will be taking him home. Outside the police station Keller Dover is waiting to confront Alex. He is certain the man knows where the missing girls are. And that's when he decides to take matters into own hands...
Breath taking and full of emotion.

Kidnapping is one of the most terrifying experiences any parent can go through. For this reason, 'Prisoners' has got to be one of the most depressing, conflicted films in recent memory. Two families nightmares become reality on Thanksgiving Day when their young daughters disappear in broad daylight. The ensuing pursuit led by the understandably enraged fathers Keller Dover (Hugh Jackman) and Franklin Birch (Terrence Howard) and their defeated wives (played by Maria Bello and Viola Davis) is dramatic, uncomfortable and shocking. There are so many twists and turns throughout this film, it's hard to say which way is up. Quickly, the focus shifts to Alex Jones, a slow young man who was driving his RV around the families' neighborhood when the girls disappeared, and Keller becomes obsessed with interrogating him after he's released due to a lack of evidence. Also integral to 'Prisoners' is detective Loki (Jake Gyllenhaal), who does his best to please Keller but is equally dedicated to following protocol and relying on his perfect record of rescuing kidnapping victims. The friction that develops between Keller and Loki is top-notch. There is also a clear theme of religion throughout 'Prisoners,' with Keller's devout Catholicism and the loss of faith recounted by Alex's aunt, Holly Jones (portrayed brilliantly by Melissa Leo). Still, there are plenty of areas for criticism of 'Prisoners,' including its runtime and the unsettling scenes of torture carried out by Keller. For this reason, he loses most of the sympathy his character had at the outset of the film, although there is an underlying sense of pity towards his character throughout the film. Much has been made of the final scene of the film, but it is a very fitting way to end such tumultuous story. While 'Prisoners' puts the grit in gritty, it is a powerful film that will remain with you long after you watch it.

My catharsis at the close of this all too real drama was a sigh of relief. Thank God it's over. That may not seem to match a 4 1/2 star rating but the relief came because now I could reflect on the movie and not endure more subjection of mystery, horror, and pure villainy. One thing is clear, the evil in this story DOES change the good people on the other side of the board. Just as in our world, evil affects us in many ways seen and unseen, despite our best beliefs that we have everything under control. Villeneuve's choices in direction, scene play, and character exploration, supported by Aaron Guzikowski's fantastic script, act as a boxer who has you pinned in the ring as he hammers at your skull and chest. You can't escape or deny the images playing out in front of you. You feel yourself in the characters and you steadily begin to relate to Jackman's descent, Gyllenhaal's determination, and Howard's indecision. This is where Prisoners offers its best. It's not in the premise of two kidnapped daughters, it's in the reasons behind why people do what they do because they've been cheated, hurt, abused, and forgotten. Melissa Leo pulls a bag over your eyes then proceeds to tell you what you see. The film reaches into depths that many would leave unanswered for fear of finding what's there. Questions of how far is too far, what is necessary, and where does wrong become right and vice versa are just the beginning in one of the toughest movies I've ever watched. Be wary if you have kids, but for anyone interested, this is worth the time and stress.

Gyllenhaal plays a dogged detective with a seemingly mild case of tourrette's (he blinks his eyes oddly and excessively).  The tale is laid out like a maze. Nothing connects in straight lines. Jackman's role as the recovered alcoholic dad who has a gut feeling he's found a suspect, and his brutality as a result of this, are a bit much, but the rest of the characters, action and screenplay are tight and amazingly executed.  It is a grim story of our being prisoners of our frailties, and how that ultimately deforms human lives.

An incredibly ambitious movie that is only, slightly, undone by its sprawling length and fairly predictable "twist" in the third act of the story.  This film isn't afraid to ask some really tough and disturbing questions, but it also has the strength to face them head on and not shy away from anything because it might be considered a sensitive subject.  The film is definitely morally complex and there's no one simple answer to the questions the film makes the audience ask.  I think that's the film's biggest positive, the fact that it doesn't shy away from the disturbing aspects of its story.  If I was put into this same situation that Keller found himself in, I don't think I'd have the heart to do what he did, even if I was a parent.  Because there's still that doubt, which Keller never had, that maybe Alex wasn't involved in the things he was accused of.  I'm gonna try my best not to spoil the film, but if I do I'll put a warning beforehand.  The things that Keller did, in his own mind, were justified because of the fact that he was doing his absolute best to get his daughter back.  Almost killing another human being, that may not have been involved, be damned.  That's the debate that the film is trying to bring up, would someone, in this same situation, have the guts to torture another human being for information he may not even be privy to.  As someone that doesn't have children, it'd be easy for me to say no at this moment in my life.  But the fact of the matter is that, at this moment, I can't see myself putting another human being through torturous hell.  Who am I to do that?  I've no right, especially when there's that doubt in your mind that maybe this person is innocent.  If I had 100% proof that this person did it, without a shadow of a doubt, I wouldn't have a problem with it.  But even if you're 99.9% sure, there's still that tiny chance that this person is innocent.  The fact that you'd have to live with that for the rest of your life.  That's gonna haunt you forever.  And even more so when what Keller did was done to someone that was a victim himself, he was a victim of the same people that kidnapped his daughter.  And this will be SPOILER-HEAVY...so skip ahead until I say.  Alex was already traumatized by the experience of being kidnapped at such a young age and being raised by the people that took him, to the point that Alex was no more than 10 years old when it came to mental age.  On top of that you have Keller beating him until his face is barely recognizable and being held hostage in the shower, where Keller would occasionally turn the shower on, from the outside, and have scalding hot water come out and burn the poor kid.  Alex will never be the same again.  By the end of the film, he's returned to his family but it's only obvious that he will never have a normal life again.  It's obvious that his family will have to suffer from the effects of the kidnapping and the abuse Keller put him through.  Keller's actions created waves that will ripple throughout the rest of Alex's life.  I don't think that's something the film really focuses on that much.  Yea, they do bring up that Keller, if found, would go to jail for what he did, but the consequences of his actions aren't fully explored.  The other interesting thing the film brings up is the fact that, whether you agree with his methods or not, Keller's actions, regardless of Alex's innocence or not, did, in fact, lead him to saving his daughter.  He doesn't save her directly, but if he hadn't tortured Alex, Loki wouldn't have found him and he wouldn't have been told by his boss to tell Alex's aunt of what happened to him, then he wouldn't have seen Alex's aunt drugging Anna, Keller's daughter, and he wouldn't have saved her.  Again, Keller indirectly saved his own daughter.  He wouldn't have been able to do this had he not tortured poor Alex.  So it raises some interesting moral conundrums.  There's no easy answer to the questions the film raises, but the film is smart enough to let you make up your own mind rather than shoving an agenda down your throat.  That's about it with the SPOILERS.  Like I said at the beginning, I did have a problem with the third act and how it became too much like a stereotypical suspense/thriller and its too long at times.  But the film benefits from a great cast, an incredible cast with one of Hugh Jackman's best performances, if not his best, and some beautiful cinematography.  So I think that makes the film easier to watch.  I don't think the film should've been cut down by much but 130 minutes would've been a perfect running length for this movie.  Regardless of that, this is still an incredible film that's definitely a very disturbing watch and it's definitely a film that's gonna haunt you long after you're done with it.

Let me start by simply saying this: if you have small children, do me a favor and do not watch this movie! As a man with no children even I was harshly affected by things that are depicted in this movie, to the point where it almost kept me up at night. Child abduction is a sad reality in our world, and I have little doubt that most parents would say they would do anything to get their kids back in that situation. What Prisoners accomplishes is putting that belief to the test...how far are you really willing to go? It seriously makes you think, and at some point you become introspective and start to wonder where you draw the line between right and wrong. That's a remarkable reaction to have when all you're doing is watching a movie. This movie is dark, bleak, and even when something positive happens you find yourself conflicted. There is no clear protagonist or antagonist for most of the film, because it shies away from black & white and takes place almost entirely in the grey. Ordinarily I'd hate that kind of ambiguity, but here it works. 

If you thought Hugh Jackman was intimidating as Wolverine you haven't seen anything yet. His portrayal of Keller is convincingly ruthless. I really believed that he was someone desperately trying to hang onto his sanity, as he fears letting his whole family down by losing his own daughter. Jake Gyllenhaal probably has the easiest role to play, because he seems to be the most level-headed of the characters. Naturally, being a police officer working the case, he has the benefit of not having as strong an emotional investment in the abductions. Yet you see him boil over occasionally as he is clearly impacted by the time spent with grieving families. I was impressed with Paul Dano's performance as a potential suspect. While he didn't have to say much, he did a great job of giving curious looks that kept you wondering whether he was hiding more than it appeared. But, for me, the best performances in Prisoners came from Terrence Howard and Viola Davis. As the parents of the other abductee they gave the viewers a relatable presence and helped ask the questions that you as a viewer were asking as well. Sadly they all but disappear in the second half of the film, which is my primary complaint.

In the first half of the movie I was so impressed with what they were doing. Although it was very violent, it wasn't gore just for the sake of gore like the Saw films. Instead it was driving the viewer to dark places and led me to question where I would morally draw the line. Do you at some point become the very evil that you seek to eliminate? That's where Terrence Howard and Viola Davis came in so handy, because they vocalized what I was feeling. This was so harsh that it was almost painful watching, but I couldn't look away because it was so well done. Yet somewhere about halfway through the film the entire story shifted gears. Suddenly it was running away from that moral debate, and into a by-the-books murder mystery. Now it is a high quality murder mystery, not a reject episode of CSI or something. It's just kind of disappointing that they changed focus so much. Even if they really wanted to switch themes it would have been nice if they gave a proper resolution to the dark road the first half led us down. No matter what Prisoners was a quality film that impacted me quite a bit. It was hard to watch, and I'm not going to seek it out again, but I'm glad I saw it.

The story focuses on two fathers named Keller Dover and Franklin Birch played by Hugh Jackman and Terrence Howard who are having a Thanksgiving dinner along with their family until both their daughters go missing. They find a car parked outside with Alex Jones inside played by Paul Dano. He attempts to run away but gets arrested. Leading the investigation is Detective David Loki played by Jake Gyllenhaal who after arresting the driver is on the search but knowing that Keller's daughter Anna's life is at stake, he himself takes matters into his own hands as a maniac is waging a war against god by killing numerous children. The movie itself basically asks you about how far would you go to protect your children. Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal were an unusual duo for the movie but they fit together very well. I haven't seen Jake in a movie for a long time which is why I wanted to watch this film badly and he was as good as always. Prisoners  gets a solid 8.5/10.

'Prisoners' is a gripping and intelligent crime thriller, that does well to portray the greatly undesirable nature of a missing person. Set in an eery American woodland town, a combination of possible suspects are gradually introduced to us, of whom the audience is able to try and solve the case themselves. Whilst when ultimately revealed you will find yourself saying "of course it was", I personally did not pinpoint the correct person. It was also interesting how the fathers attempt to take matters into their own hands, but ultimately make things worse for themselves; whilst interestingly justifying the title of the film. The two leads portray their characters well; particularly Gyllenhaal.

Despite its considerable length, the film itself did not seem to drag, instead remaining intense and interesting. Whilst each of the components to the case were infact intelligent, the ending left me somewhat disappointed. Many questions were left unanswered, with character links hard to define. A reliance on weak psychological reasoning  for the crime was also unsatisfactory. Of course this may have all been intended, but the links that were provided did seem somewhat desperate, making me want to give the director of the film a call to answer a couple of queries. Despite this, I thoroughly enjoyed this crime thriller, just falling short of 4 stars due to the question provoking ending.

The only complaints I have with this movie is the casting choice for Detective Loki & the lack of screen time for Terrance Howard's character. All else was great with special mention to Hugh Jackman for an emotional performance.

Review:
I found this movie to be extremely deep and full of intense drama throughout. I did have to watch it in 2 parts the length of the film, at 2 and a half hours, was quite much to keep up with, in that mood. There's loads of twists and turns throughout the movie which keeps it interesting, and the acting from all of the cast was great. The director should have shown some more of the other family that is also going through hell and the ending was left up to the audience to put together, which was a bit weird after getting drawn into the families trauma. The storyline is very well put together and it really does make the audience feel that they are going through the situation with the characters. In all its a great watch but it's quite long. Watchable!

Round-Up:
Hugh Jackman really does show a different side to his usual acting style. If it wasn't for his in depth performance, this movie wouldn't have been half as good. All of the other characters also bring reality to the film which makes the intensity throughout the movie a great watch. Although the film is quite long, I don't think that I would take anything out of the movie. It does flow well and the director really did cover every aspect of a bad situation that every is going through. I don't think that I would have gone with that type of ending, but in all, it's entertaining and enjoyable.

This movie is the true example of what our standards for movie making should be, so take out the BS of money and BLOCKBUSTERS and focus on what is the whole point of movies. To entertain and tell a story. If I was in Hugh Jackman's shoes, in the situation of my child being abducted from me. i would do whatever it takes to get my child back.

I swear indie filmmakers often pen half of what would be a complete story. End it on a cliffhanger, with the idea that the viewer will decide what the overall message was. 

I don't like that. 

This film was brilliant, and could have had a clear ending, one that would have tied the loose ends and been a complete story. Instead I feel the same way I do when a great tv episode ends with "to be continued". Except there is no continuation, no finality. I feel that kind of story writing is half assed, in the name of being "artsy". Nevertheless "Prisoners" is definitely worth seeing.
