Powerful and completely absorbing, Prisoners is an emotionally exhausting criminal thriller, whose dreadful tonality and ethical questions asked are at least to be called disturbing. A haunting story with mesmerizing performances this movie is a gritty and intensive piece of film-making which in spite of being a bit overlong, constitutes Jean Villeneuve as one of the very interesting Canadian director exports to Hollywood.

The movie delves deeper into one of the biggest fears of parents: kidnapping and possible death of their young, beloved children. In a very straight-forward manner, director Denis Villeneuve throws the audience into a complex story which with the time turns into an ethical exploration and bold film-making. Franklin Rich (Terrence Howard) and Keller Dover (Hugh Jackman)'s daughters are kidnapped on Thanksgiving and it is Detective Loki (Jake Gyllenhaal) who is appointed the task of discovering them. Quickly, Keller decides that he should take things in his hands and challenges Loki's detective methods. By trying to find his daughter, Keller challenges the audience throughout the whole movie with the question: how far could he go; how far is ethically, morally acceptable. All these questions are at moments strengthen or weakened by the police procedures, the religious and emotional complexity of the whole movie.

It is true that Prisoners is much longer than necessary and that the pacing is not an example for a breath-taking criminal thriller.It is also true that the very experienced fans of the genre, with an eye for details, would probably solve the mystery towards the middle of the movie. Still,thanks to the wonderful performances of Gyllenhaal and Jackman, combined with Villeneuve's ability to stretch the emotions and to upset the audience ,this movie turns into a 140 minute challenge, which is worth-investing in.  Then after, the final credits, just like in his previous masterpiece, Incendies, Villeneuve lets the viewers confused and challenged both emotionally and philosophically.

Despite the early-Oscar buzz, Prisoners will most probably fall short of earning Oscar nods or awards. Nevertheless, this movie is a wonderful opening of the Awards season and a must see for all types of moviegoers: from fans of the genre, to casual blockbuster viewers.

2 and a half hour makes this film almost unbearable and tiring to watch. But, what it makes up for that long stretch of viewing is the depth of the emotional landscape in between scenes. Not your ordinary abduction movie.

Keller Dover (Hugh Jackman) as he searches for his daughter and her friend who have disappeared. Unlike his previous films which focus on the heights people will rise to in desperate situations, Prisoners focuses on the depths they will sink to at their most desperate. It's not an easy film, but it explores some big questions about right and wrong. It also boasts some spectacular performances, particularly Viola Davis as the mother of Joy, one of the abducted girls. She is, for my money, the best actress currently working in Hollywood and once again manages to steal the screen every time she is on it. 

Prisoners biggest weakness is in its under use of many of its actors. I know that to give them all parts as big as Jackman's and Jake Gyllenhaal would create an overly bloated film, but overall there is a feeling of an attempt at an ensemble piece, that was high jacked by the leads. It's not that Jackman and Gyllenhaal are not up to the task that's been given to them, but that the supporting cast have risen above and beyond and therefore overshadow them a bit. In addition to Davis, Paul Dano is wonderful as the suspected abductor in another role with very little dialogue and Melissa Leo is pitch perfect as his guardian. I want to see these peoples perspectives in addition to that of Keller Dover. 

There is also an issue with the ending, with the motives behind the girls abduction left murky and unclear. This is a small gripe however as that is not what the film is about. It would have been nice to have a slightly shorter running time as well as it starts to drag and degrade into a cheap thriller with too much exposition in the final moments. 

Overall Prisoners is an interesting character study and it is nice to see a film that doesn't treat life as a Disney film.

Oh my word...so Im just late to the party but I bought PRISONERS yesterday after everyone telling me to see it. This is not only one of the best films of the year but one of the greatest thrillers I have ever seen. Honestly I think it beats Finchers 7. This film is masterfully directed and has an amazing script. Tension just everywhere. Several scenes are "holy shit" worthy. I think the heart of the film both lies in Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal who give the finest performances Ive ever seen from them. Roger Deakins who shot the film deserves an Oscar for his work as the town has this blue murky tint to it that just makes it that much scarier. On a side note Paul Dano is creepy as shit as a suspect but the real scary one is another suspect who is played by the actor from TDK who is the paranoid schizophrenia Joker helper. He has this face that just doesnt look human. This film needs to be used in screenwriting classes on how to build tension through a 2.5 hour run time. I was hooked from the opening shot and didnt look away until the credits rolled.
Excellent movie right up until the end.

A difficult to watch dramatic masterpiece given life by impeccable acting, brilliant direction, and a harrowing concept. Prisoners was far more than what I hoped it would be and its stars Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal gave seamless dramatic performances worthy of praise. The endlessly talented Paul Dano was so expertly reserved that halfway through the movie, you may forget that he's acting at all - you might actually believe that he is the character he's portraying. The supporting cast was flawless and the direction was superb. Here is a wonderful slice of modern cinema glory. I would share this any time.

I read some negative reviews about this one from my RT friends... and I really could not understand why! Maybe we are on a different page here, or more on a different wavelength, but for me this thriller directed by Denis Villeneuve, with cinematography by Roger Deakins, was exciting, and thought provoking, emotional, engaging and with outstanding acting. What a cast! Hugh Jackman, Jake Gyllenhaal, Viola Davis, Maria Bello, Melissa Leo, and Paul Dano  - for me the weakest point was Terrence Howard, but even his acting was satisfactory enough not to criticize it too much. 

Building up the plot was so natural and easy going that the later part focusing on the actual abduction of two young girls in Pennsylvania and the resulting search to find them, was a logical follow up with enough twists and smart clues to keep us all glued to the seats. 
Excellently developed character of Keller Dover (Hugh Jackman), a deeply religious man who runs a struggling carpentry business, from the beginning when he attends a Thanksgiving dinner with his family at the house of their neighbours, the Birches, was carrying most of the story "on his shoulders" with the help of  detective Loki (Jake Gyllenhaal). I enjoyed every second watching these two actors showing us the real master actors at work! Very powerful performances which could not be ignored. 

The emotional complexity will take you from the first few minutes and you will sense a sense of dread that makes for absorbing viewing which could disturb some viewers. I liked the movie, I liked the story, I liked the acting... recommended for everyone I know!

By mixing a murder mystery with a revenge story we get something a little bit different. Jake Gyllenhaal seems to reprise his "zodiac" role but seems to be the only cop with a clue. Hugh Jackman plays the unhinged father who will do anything to get his daughter back. Unfortunately both characters get in the others' way. The "whodunnit" aspect is handled really well with plenty of twists and turns and wondering whether people are innocent victims or defiant perpetrators.The cast is pretty strong although there's little focus on the other three parents which is a shame. There's also a lot of "why didn't they just do that" scenarios where the case should/could have been solved but the film does show the police aren't that effective - although I'd have thought a specialised team would have been called out. That aside an interesting and tense film.
When you mix the suspense from the lovely bones and drama from the zodiac you get an unforgettable thriller.
Powerful and unforgettable film.  One of the best of the year.

"Prisoners" is a dark and very effective tale of disappearance of two young girls on Thanksgiving and the ensuing search led by Police Detective Loki (Jake Gyllenhaal). When the prime suspect, introverted teenager (Paul Dano), is released, one of the fathersm Keller Dover (Hugh Jackman) decides to take matters into his own hands in very gruesome fashion.

This is definitely one of the year's best acting ensembles with the cast also including Maria Bello as Jackman's wife who falls into deep depression and Terrence Howard and Viola Davis as the two other parents who Jackman's character tries to involve in his plans. Howard and Davis's couple are the opposite of Jackman-Bello with Howard the more vulnerable and Davis attempting to showcase strength. But it is Jackman who excels  in delivering another career-best performance after his exceptional, Oscar-nominated work last year in "Les Miserables" as a very tough and aggressive man who lets his fatherly instincts get the best of him. Melissa Leo is also exceptional in a brief role as Dano's aunt who raised him. Dano is also very good as the psychologically disturbed character. The movie's weak spot is Gyllenhaal but his acting is not at fault with the script mostly to blame for his character's lack of development. He embodies the character's obsession with the case (plus the occasional twitches) but other than that we know nothing about this key character. 

The movie works well as both the story of a father and as a mystery. There are so many elements to the plot and multiple characters are introduced that all come full circle by the film's end that is very difficult to predict (despite my best efforts). There is not a single scene that is redundant, which is a testament to the film's great writing (kudos to screenwriter's Aaron Guzikowski, who only has 2012's mediocre "Contraband" to his credit, for this original story). Canadian director Denis Villeneuvue (who helmed 2011's Oscar nominated "Incendies") does an excellent job here in creating a very grim atmosphere throughout. This is by no means an easy movie-going experience - you will be attentive and at the edge of your seat throughout its 2hr30min running time.
From the trailers it looked interesting, but after watching it for half an hour I got bored. Wanted to fast forward to the end.
Unforgettable script & performances from an awesome thriller movie that pushes the limit on what those individuals will do on such desperate moments! A must see!!!
The most unsatisfying movie of the year!

Keller Dover: Pray for the best, but prepare for the worst.

I did expect much after first trailer, but this has left me speechless. From start to finish movie will keep you at the edge of your seat, and last movie with that kind of intensity was 'The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo' (2011). Absolutely outstanding script and performances. The casting and acting are amazing, especially Jake Gyllenhaal who gave a wonderful performance as the detective. Hugh Jackman also did a great work as Keller Dover. Atmosphere in the movie was over-the-top, similar to 'Se7en' and 'Zodiac'. I read one good comment for Prisoners and I tend to fully agree: "things were slow sometimes but it only adds to the beauty of the big picture.". I love the way this movie is made. It's very realistic and it's dark. The music was top notch. The verdict, this is an excellent thriller with some of the best performances and I highly recommend it. Very well done.

"Pray for the best, but prepare for the worst."

Prisoners is a dark thriller that will have you at the edge of your seat during almost the entirety of the film. It was a very intense experience. It is hard not to compare this film to Mystic River or Gone Baby Gone because those two movies set the landmark for modern thrillers dealing with abduction. Prisoners almost lives up to the standards that those two films set. Canadian director, Denis Villeneuve, follows up his Oscar nominated film, Incendies, with this intense thriller that manages to capture the audiences attention once again. Incendies was one of my favorite films of 2011, and despite Prisoners not living up to the perfection that film achieved, I still thought this film was highly entertaining and satisfying. There were a few minor plot points that didn't work for me, but that didn't take anything away from this great film. It is a more mainstream film, but it manages to follow a similar approach as Fincher reminding us of Se7en or Zodiac thanks to its dark and haunting atmosphere. I am a huge fan of this genre and really had a fun time trying to solve the mystery through the small clues that Villeneuve masterfully presented in the story. Prisoners was without a doubt one of the most gripping and intense experiences I had all year. Unfortunately it is a little too intense and at times I felt the film could have used some moments to release such tension. Anyways Prisoners is a highly recommended film and a must-see. 

Keller Dover (Hugh Jackman) is a family man who is always prepared for the worst. He is a survivalist with a basement full of provisions and is teaching his older son, Ralph (Dylan Minnette), how to hunt. He's married to Grace (Maria Bello) and they have a daughter named Anna (Erin Gerasimovich). One afternoon, Keller's worst nightmare comes true while they are hanging out with their friendly neighbors the Birches. Franklin (Terrence Howard) and Nancy Birch (Viola Davis) have two kids about the same age as Ralph and Grace, Eliza (Zoe Borde) and Joy (Kyla Drew Simmons). While the two families are having a lovely time together, Joy and Anna decide to go back to Anna's house, but when the Dover's come back home they are horrified to discover that the kids never made it back. Ralph remembers that they were playing next to a strange RV that was parked up front which is now gone. Detective Loki (Jake Gyllenhaal) is appointed as the lead investigator in the case and the first thing he does is locate the RV. The driver is a disturbed young man named Alex Jones (Paul Dano) who has the IQ of a 10 year old and with no evidence to incriminate him Detective Loki has to let him free. His Aunt (Melissa Leo) comes to pick him up and explains how naive and innocent he is. As hours pass, Keller begins to get more desperate and convinced that Alex was involved he decides to take matters into his own hands. From here on the tension begins to escalate as they try to solve the mystery.

Prisoners succeeds as a neo-noir thriller building up a lot of tension with a very dark atmosphere which is perfectly captured by cinematographer Roger Deakins. It adds to the mysterious mood of the story which on its own is already pretty intense. The screenplay, written be Aaron Guzikowski (Contraband), is very well written with a very interesting premise and some great twists. My only complaint with this film has to do with the lack of a strong female character. With such a strong cast, I thought that Maria Bello or Viola Davis could have been given a stronger role, but the film focuses mostly on Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal. They both give very strong and convincing performances, and Gyllenhaal has surprised me over the last three years with very good films (Source Code, End of Watch, and now this one). I guess he has been choosing his roles very wisely lately because his next film also looks interesting (Enemy which is also directed by Denis Villeneuve). Paul Dano also gave a strong performance as his character's motivations were very hard to decipher. The strong cast and the interesting story make this a very entertaining film despite some minor flaws involving character motivations. It is one of the best recent thrillers coming out of Hollywood and I doubt you will be disappointed.

Tense and disturbing, Prisoners does not have guns and expensive special effects, it settles for the electrifying tension and the unsettling mood, which is what makes it so good.

Described by some journalists as an allegory for how America handles national security issues, what is clearly the most evocative issue at hand is how far a parent would go to protect their child. Questions raised by this difficult watch are buried as the film descends into a typical mystery thriller in its closing act and closes almost perverse for the sake of it ending that's blatant ironic twist just about spits smug superiority at its audience. Until then, it's an uncomfortable, brooding drama.
